segments.text: Welcome.
Welcome to Fearless with Jason Whitlock.
I am Jason Whitlock.
Happy hump day.
Happy Harmony Day.
We'll have some Tennessee Harmony as we do every Wednesday,
Pastor Bobby and Pastor Anthony will be here.
We're going to delve a little deeper into toxic masculinity.
We talked about manhood last week with Pastor Bobby and Pastor Anthony.
We're going to go a little bit deeper today and talk about toxic masculinity.
We also have a couple of special guests, or at least one.
Well, we got two special guests, actually.
Bill O'Reilly.
No spin news.
BillOReilly.com.
Bill O'Reilly, the big Fox News superstar.
He's going to join us on today's show.
We'll talk a little Afghanistan.
We'll perhaps get his reaction.
Remember, Megan Kelly was on the show and had some interesting things to say about Bill.
We'll get his reactions to her comments.
Can't wait to talk to the big man, Bill O'Reilly.
Mark Schleart, former NFL star.
He's going to join us very shortly because I'm going to begin today.
Talking about COVID and what's going on in the NFL.
We'll get Mark Schleart.
You guys remember, Jimmy, you know Mark Schleart, a good friend of the show.
Great human being.
One of the best guys I know.
I love Mark.
We'll probably disagree on my take on this COVID and Cam Newton and Bill Bella check.
Or we'll do it for Bronco, player.
So you have all that and more to look forward to.
But as we like to do on this show.
Yeah, I'm going to start by starting a fire.
Based on his comments Wednesday morning, it's fair to conclude Bill Bella check is no fan of the NFL's
nonsensical and highly divisive COVID protocols.
The Patriots head coach started his day meeting with the media.
For about 10 minutes, reporters probe football's greatest coach for insight into the reasoning that
caused the team to cut starting quarterback Cam Newton.
Bella check provided no such insight.
He dived every direct question concerning Cam and pivoted to offering not so subtle
gripes about the league's convoluted and authoritarian COVID protocols.
When asked if Cam's unvaccinated status contributed to his departure.
Here's how Bella check responded.
Did Cam's vaccination status have anything to do with him being released?
No.
No, I mean, look, you guys keep talking about that.
And, you know, I would just point out that I don't know what the number is.
I mean, you guys can look it up.
I mean, I think it's a lot of information, but the number of players and coaches and staff
members that have, you know, been infected by COVID in this training camp who have been
vaccinated is a pretty high number.
So I wouldn't lose sight of that.
Later in the press conference, a reporter asked a second question regarding Cam's vaccination
status and the impact of Cam missing practice because of the league's COVID protocols.
Here's that clip.
Yeah, but other players on the team weren't vaccinated as I would say probably does every
other team in the league.
And we've had a minimal, but throughout the league, there have been a number of quite
a high number, I would say, of players who have had the virus who have been vaccinated.
So, you know, your implication that vaccination solves every problem is just not really, I
would say that that has not been substantiated based on what's happened in training camp
this year.
That's all.
All right, let's be clear here.
The reporter did not imply anything.
Bella check knows this.
He knows the NFL and the NFL PA have implied that the vaccine solves every problem.
He knows that's not true.
He knows the NFL isn't forcing the vaccine on his players out of concern for their safety.
They're doing it to appease critics of football.
They're doing it to align with the big tech social media overlords.
The NFL knows that if it doesn't bully its players in it taking the vaccine, corporate
media will double and triple down on their assault on football.
Roger Goodell and the league's office have spent the past decade trying to make peace
with their enemies through appeasement.
Who is the NFL's enemy?
The political left.
The people determined to tear down the patriarchy.
The feminists who labeled masculinity as toxic.
The alleged journalists who have distorted football's concussion issue, the woke warriors who want
to end football.
It's all connected.
The NFL thinks fighting for football means making peace with people who hate football.
It's not going to happen.
Last year the NFL bowed to the Black Lives Matter mob.
The league draped itself in marked sociology and utopian slogans.
This year it's embracing pandemic panic.
Forcing young men in relatively perfect health to inject an experimental drug is ludicrous.
The NFL played an entire season a year ago with no one vaccinated.
Did one NFL player die?
Did any NFL player get hospitalized during the season with COVID?
These players are not all stupid sheep.
They know the COVID survival rate.
They know older, fat, unhealthy people are the people who should be taking extra precautions.
They know the NFL has no business getting this deep into their medical decisions.
Soldiers Bill Belichick, a reporter asked him to cite the number of unvaccinated
Patriot players listen to this response.
How many players on the team are still not vaccinated?
Yeah, again, I'm not going to get into that.
Those are all personal decisions and it's not my place to talk about another person's decision or medical condition.
What's going on in the NFL is a joke.
It not only violates the players' personal rights, it violates the unifying tenets of team sports.
Vaccinated and unvaccinated players are being treated differently in things as small as where they can eat in team facilities
and what they can eat at the team facility.
Unvaccinated players have to report to the facility much earlier than unvaccinated players.
It's all stupid.
It's all theater to appease the media.
Most of the vaccinated, including the coaches, took the vaccine under personal protest.
You can't convince me a group of mostly 20-something men believe getting the vaccine is in their best interest.
The NFL is immersed in the same political theater as the rest of the country.
Sports used to be a leader.
Now sports leagues are followers.
I'm as frustrated as Bill Belichick.
All right.
Let's roll out to Denver, Colorado and visit with a good friend of mine and Uncle Jimmy's colleague at Fox Sports 1 for several years.
Mark Slayer, three-time Super Bowl champion, expert NFL radio and television analyst.
Mark, you've heard my rant.
I think the unvaccinated players are being completely unfairly.
Do you agree?
Well, let me say this, that I don't necessarily disagree with you, but I don't wholeheartedly agree with you.
And the reason I say it that way, Jason, is because it's never been fair.
Decisions are always made based upon the information given.
Fastest 40 guys get extra opportunity.
The most talented guys get extra opportunities.
I have been turned down for three jobs in free agency because of my injury history.
The Atlanta Falcons turn me down.
The Chicago Bears turn me down.
The Indianapolis Colts turn me down.
The doctor of the Atlanta Falcons said you have the needs of an 80-year-old woman I wouldn't sign you.
I went on to play six more years and went to more world championships.
So it's always been that way when you are given a choice, like the players have been given a choice to get vaccinated or not to get vaccinated, there are also consequences that come with that.
And so they are dealing with those consequences.
That's always been the case in the National Football League is you make a choice.
There are consequences associated with that choice.
And I would say this, availability becomes very important.
Responsibility becomes very important.
And you have a responsibility to be available to your football team.
And if this gives you even it's only a 20% greater chance of being available, well, that to me is worth taking a vaccine for as a player.
And I will tell you, listen, man, I guarantee you, I'm not going to be able to do that.
I guarantee you, if it comes down to the vaccinated player versus the unvaccinated player and all things are equal and they're talking about a guy running down on special teams, making a play.
And they NFL teams will choose the vaccinated player because he has more of an ability or more of a likelihood of getting through and being available than the unvaccinated player does.
That's probably 20%.
But those are the decisions being made inside of inside of facilities the last two days.
So that's the way the NFL works.

Mark, I can't disagree with anything you said, but I still don't think it's right because they've set up rules to favor the sheep who can be easily bullied into taking a vaccine that they just don't need.
These are 20 to 32 year old men in excellent health for the most part.
The all the statistics say that, you know, they're not going to be harmed by COVID.
The survival rate and the death rate for people in their age group with their health status.
Again, nothing's going to happen to them.
And I felt like and I want you to take on this.

I felt like I heard some frustration from Bill Belichick that he thinks like I think like, man, we've created a bunch of rules that are actually divisive within our locker room and have complicated this football process in an unnecessary way.
I think Bill Belichick is sympathetic to the unvaccinated players.
Oh, I don't think there's any question that he's sympathetic because it makes it hard for him.
I mean, it makes it harder for you as an organization because you have to jump through all these hoops and you're being monitored by Big Brother.
So it definitely makes it harder on Bill Belichick.
So I don't think there's any question about that, but it's not about being a 32 year old or a 29 year old and having less likelihood of being sick.
It's really about how old is Bill Belichick? He's pushing 70.
It's your coaching staff. It's the people within your building that you're in contact with all the time.
Those are the people at further risk. Like I got vaccinated.
Jason, I got vaccinated as soon as I could.
And there are several concerns that I had. I've had about almost lost my career in 1993 with about of Guillaume Beret, which is a Guillaume Beret is an auto immune deficiency.
I lost all the feeling my arms and legs for the better part of a half a year.
Lost a ton of weight was very sick. Didn't think my career or there were times I didn't think my career would continue.
And so I was concerned about getting vaccinated. The bottom line is I have a mom who's suffering with cancer.
I want to be with her as much as I can. I have young, you know, I have a family.
I want to make sure that I'm protecting the people within my family, my father, my mother that are in their 80s as much as I can.
So when you're in a football organization, like you say what you want about the business side of it, but it becomes family.
And it's more about all the people. You know, my head trainer just retired, Steve Anthony when I was with Denver after 45 years of being a trainer in that building.
So it's those people that we have to protect or at least the NFL is looking at the team in totality.
So yeah, is he frustrated? Sure he's frustrated. Is it a lot more hoops to have to jump through? Absolutely.
But the bottom line is winning championships and being a great organization is not about you, the individual.
It's not about whether you're going to get sick or whether you're going to get your shine or not. It's about us as a team.
What is best for the whole? And I think that's where, like, that's where my opinion difference differs from a lot of people's opinion when it comes to the unfair nature.

And I'm used to the unfair nature. We're all treated fairly, but we're not all traded equally. Just ask any superstar that walks inside the building as opposed to a guy that's at the end of the roster like me.
It's a there's a big difference in the way you're treated.
The thing that Bella check is saying and the thing that I'm agreeing with and I think most people know, we don't know if the vaccine provides protection for people.
Israel, I believe, is the most vaccinated country on the planet. 90% and they're having all kinds of problems.
So it's all speculation. And so if I'm Bella check or Lamar Jackson or Cole Beasley, it's like, y'all just want me to go off speculation.
Mark, let me ask you this and I'll let you end on this note. You have a son who was a professional baseball player.
Let's wind the clock back and say he's 22 years old and he doesn't have kids yet because that is my concern is like reproductive issues and down the road.
You're 22 year old son. You would want him to take this vaccine to be forced into taking this vaccine to play in Major League Baseball.
I would want him to take the vaccine because I think it gives you the best chance of mitigating the results of getting COVID.
If you haven't had it already, if you haven't already been exposed to it and have the natural antibodies, I think it gives you the best chance of mitigating the potential issues of COVID.
And obviously there are many and there's a lot of stuff that is unknown. I understand that, Jason, but yes, I would encourage him to take it.
And that's just where I stand on the vaccine.
Mark, I appreciate you doing this. You're one of my favorite people in the sports media business.
Mark's a believer. I don't think he reminds me sharing that. And he just comes to things from such an honest perspective.
Miss you, man. Love you.
I miss you too. And I love you. And I want to tell you something.

I had this conversation three weeks ago with my dear friend, who was my coach since I was a freshman in high school that I talked to every week who refused to get vaccinated and passed away a couple of days ago from COVID.
And I just spoke at his funeral. So, you know, it's topic to me that's that that hits home. And this is a guy that I talked to weekly and for the last 40 years.
And so, you know, I mean, I just want to give people the best opportunity to live long, full lives. So that's where I'm at.
Well, as uncle Jimmy just went through COVID here in Nashville and it certainly shook me up and has me eating better and on a diet and trying to do all the things you can do to protect yourself.
I need to get into, you know, marks in shape like he's 35 years old. I need to I need to try to get there.
Listen, man, Mark is a class act. Mark is a class act. I mean, if there's anything that I can just maybe pick a pick him apart for is the fact that he had that little stint in Denver.
Other than that, man, I mean, the man is a class act.
You guys know I got to run, but I love you both. Man, I miss you both.
Thank you, thank you, thank you, Mark. I thought you was going to do your Jimmy from Denver routine that we used to do in the on radio.
Remember, he's used to call in Jimmy, but you do realize what year that was in then.
What year that was back then that was fashionable. Track that joke.
Huge Broncos fan, Jimmy from Denver. He used to call the radio show all the time.
Huge.
No, we can't correct that joke and I'm not laughing at that. I'm laughing at the fact that Jimmy is making me think about how funny that was years ago.
But now it's not funny at all.
Jimmy's making me think about it.
Yeah, I had.
He told you a prank. Don't go there.
All right, let's move to a better topic.
My good friends and good ranchers.
Oh, yes, because I'm your best friend.
Yeah, when you're preparing for a nice cookout at home, look at good ranchers.
When you're hungry for a great meal for your entire family, look at good ranchers.
When you're wanting to save money, but still have great quality food, look at good ranchers.
They provide some of the best chicken and beef I've ever tasted and it can be delivered safely to your home right now.
Good ranchers, meals are all 100% American farm raise and that's one of the many reasons why I love using them here in Nashville.
If you subscribe, you'll get $20 off and free express shipping.
Get steakhouse quality for less than $5 per meal. Go to goodranchers.com slash fearless to get $20 off and free express shipping.
And just, I'm just, people are starting to reach out to me, a friend of mine in Kansas City, Susie May reached out to me this morning.
I'm like, wait a minute. You're losing weight. You're looking incredible.
You know what I honestly told her, I text her, I said, good ranchers.
Good ranchers is helping me do it.
This good, I'm just eating better and good ranchers is a part of that.
That's goodranchers.com slash fearless.
Don't go anywhere.
Welcome back. Welcome back to fearless with Jason Whitlock.
Alright Uncle Jimmy, sure. We got a big guess. This is the big dog.
Yeah, I don't know if it gets any bigger than this.
We got the big man, Bill O'Reilly. You guys know him, of course, from his days at Fox News.
He now has the NoSpin News and bill O'Reilly.com.
Bill O'Reilly, welcome to Fearless with Jason Whitlock. We are honored to have you.
Well, that's very nice of you to say Jason. First of all, I apologize for the lighting.
We're fearless here too, but we can't seem to fix these lights, but at least you can hear me, right?
You can hear me alright?
I can hear you perfectly, Bill, and I wouldn't worry about the lighting.
You look better in the dark anyway.
You know that's true, Jason. And you're very kind to say that, by the way, but that is absolutely true.
Bill, you can return to favor and say the same thing to him.
Hey, Bill, we were just talking with former NFL player Mark Slareth, and I'm wondering, are you following this NFL, COVID deal, controversy?
Bill Belichick today, I thought, pretty much came out as anti-vax mandate.
They kept trying to ask him questions about Cam Newton, and he kept pushing him back in the sand.
Look, man, we don't know what's going on with this vaccine. We've had vaccinated people catch COVID.
We've had unvaccinated people catch COVID.
I felt like Belichick made it kind of clear that he thinks the NFL is wrong for trying to force these young guys into taking the vaccine.
Have you been following us at all? You have a take on what the NFL is doing?
Yep.
Well, if I were the NFL commissioner, I would issue a mandate that all players had to be vaccinated.
And I would do that for a public safety reason, because as you know, Jason, I mean, players are in very close proximity to each other.
And football is obviously a contact sport.
So for the safety of the players themselves, I would say if you want to be an active player, you have to be vaccinated.
If you choose not to be vaccinated, we're not going to punish you or cut you, but you'll be on the inactive list.
Okay? And the union will work out some kind of payment schedule, whatever that may be.
But that's what I would do. As far as Cam Newton is concerned, I don't think this has to do with the Vax.
I think it has to do with his diminishing abilities on the field.
So if you look at the New England Patriot roster, they're obviously going to start the Alabama guy, Mac Jones.
They got a good guy behind Jones. Hoyer has been around forever. Knows the system can mentor Jones.
They save about $2 million cutting Cam Newton.
So it's a business decision. Newton didn't perform that well last year. He just didn't look that sharp in preseason.
He's not as quick as he used to be. And I'm an old college quarterback, and I can see this stuff.
His arm strength isn't quite what it used to be. Now, he can still play in the league.
But if you've got a Mac Jones on the ascent and you paid him a lot of money as a first draft choice, you're going with him.
And to back up, Hoyer is cheaper than Cam Newton.
So I think it was much more of a business decision there than a Vax decision.
I got a say, Bill. Bill, I won his job. He clearly wants my job. He should be a sports commentator.
And I got to be honest, you played quarterback in college? elaborate a little bit.
Well, I was basically the place kicker and the punter and the backup quarterback schedule to start my senior, my junior year at Marist College.
But then I decided to go abroad and be an intellectual, Jason. So I went to the University of London, forfeited my junior year and came back and I played my senior year.
But I was more of a backup quarterback, but I know the position and I know the game. In high school, I played ice hockey. I played semi-pro baseball.
I played CYO basketball. So I've always been engaged in sports myself. And I have taken a very rapid interest in it because I think sports is a great American institution.
Great place to escape, a great place to compete. And if you want to know anything about sports, Jason, here I am. I'm ready to go.
I can tell. Now, I will say this. You kind of shocked me saying that you would force the players to be vaccinated. You kind of sounded like Joe Biden there for a second when I was listening.
No, no, but it's a different... I'm coming at it from a different point of view because it's not like most other professions.
Football, pro football is a dangerous profession. It's dangerous. And NFL stands for not for long average tenure in the league is about three years.
So you've got to protect the health of the players. And every piece of evidence says that taking the vaccine makes a person safer.
So that's the point of view I'm coming from, not from a political point of view or anything like that.

All right. Let me move you into politics and help educate me. Outrage has become so normalized that it's hard for me to judge when the outrage is genuine and whether or not is it a reflection of reality.
And so you're the veteran newsman. You've been following this. You've written a lot of books about political history and whatnot.
How outrage should we be about what's transpired in Afghanistan and Joe Biden's responsibility for what has transpired in Afghanistan?
Is it really as bad as people are making it out to be?
It's bad. I don't know if outrage is the best word here. I think concern for your country because we have weak leadership now. President Biden is a weak man.

He's diminished and he apparently lives in a world of delusion. Any president that would come on television three days after 13 American service people are blown up by terrorists in Afghanistan and say,
we did an extraordinarily excellent job evacuating people from Kabul. Anybody who would say that is delusional.
So rather than I was angry that the service people got killed, I was angry that Joe Biden looked at his watch while the coffins were going by him and do over Delaware.
But I'm more concerned based upon Biden's performance in eight months. And if he was in the NFL, he would have been cut. He would have been cut Jason.
All right, because it's been an abysmal performance. And for me covering politics for most 50 years and knowing every single president, I wrote books on him as you mentioned, he's diminished.
He's not going to make a comeback. All right. And that's frightening to me as an American citizen.

What do you say to people? And I was just a young kid at this time, but I remember in the last three, four, maybe the entire last four years of Ronald Reagan's presidency, people argued that he was cognitively diminished.
Is there any comparison there?

Well, he was diminished, but it wasn't in his last term. It was in his first term right after he was nearly assassinated. And I wrote, I think, the best book on Ronald Reagan called Killing Reagan, where he was this close to dying.
And it took him a good year to recover from that. In the meantime, he was serving as president of the United States. And his mental acuity declined. And there's no doubt about it.
But then Reagan made a miraculous comeback. And I guess that's possible for Joe Biden as well. All right. But this was a physical injury.
You know, and people forget how close President Reagan came to dying. And that kind of a trauma on the body takes a while.
And he was, you know, a fairly elderly man to begin with. So there's not a comparison between Reagan and Biden because of the physical problems that Reagan had.

Biden, if you look, I had Joseph Lieberman, the former senator from Connecticut on the No Spin News last night. And I asked him, I said, you've known Biden for decades. You serve with him in the Senate.
Is this a diminished man? And Lieberman said, yes. Now, that's an eyewitness knows Biden really well. And Lieberman's a Democrat.
So I don't think there's any question about it.
Bill, you obviously reached him was a part of taking cable news and making it pervasive throughout American culture.
I'm someone that kind of believes that cable news has not been good for American culture. I don't think we're more informed.
You know, I think our emotions are played with more often. And so I kind of want your take as a historian.
Are we more informed in this era of cable news coverage as opposed to previous generations when it was a Walter Kankai or, you know, there was less perversion of the news?
Are we more informed in this generation or just more outrage?
It's an excellent question and a complex question. I started my career in 1976 coming out of Boston University with a master's degree in broadcast journalism.
And I worked my way up. I started in Scranton, Pennsylvania, worked my way up to the network news.
And I was a correspondent under Dan Rather at CBS under Peter Jennings at ABC.
The news back then was fairly straightforward. The news divisions were not mandated to make billions of dollars. That was the difference.
The standard was you've got to tell the truth and back it up. You have to do that. And the people in place were very skilled at doing that.

Okay, Peter Jennings was a brilliant man. So then what happened and it's partially my fault was when I was at Harvard getting a master's degree in public administration, I understood the technology was changing.
And there was going to be 24 hour news presentation. So I invented a program that ultimately became known as the O'Reilly factor.
It was a commentary program based upon facts. All right, and I do that to this day. My commentary is not ideological. It's not party driven. It's based on facts. I can back up everything I say.
Well, that program, as you know, was the biggest program ever in cable news. It exploded Fox News. It brought a whole new corporate mentality to the news.
And that's the key because they made so much money doing news analysis that standard started to fly out the window. Now, I believe I kept them until I left Fox News close to five years ago.
But now it's you say this because we want our audience, whether it's conservative or liberal or watch us. And we're not that interested whether it's true or not.
And that is the deterioration. And then you have the newspapers doing the same thing. New York Times does not cover the news for everybody. It covers the news for liberal people.
Same thing with the Washington Post. So they know where the money is and that's where they go. And the truth be damned in many areas.
Bill, you've said a mouthful. I want to ask you specifically and I don't know if you can comment. What do you think of Fox News in your absence, in the absence of Roger Ells?
And particularly on the other side of this election where they seem to have somewhat abandoned their audience and seem to be in a fight with their audience.
What's your take on Fox News and how they're covering the news now?
They have some very skilled people at Fox News and they're brilliant marketers and they have a ton of money to get their message out.

It's not the place now that it was when I was there. And some people say, well, Riley, you're part of the problem. Ted Koppel said I ruined the television news industry. He said that's right on my own show.
So I don't want to get into some antics about who was better, who was worse, what the standards were or what the standards are now.
But what has changed there is the money factor that the executives running the show are now judged on how much profit they can bring in.
I don't know if anyone in a managerial position at Fox News or CNN that has any news experience at all.
They're business people.

So buyer beware. I tell my audience, and this obviously gives me a huge advantage in the blaze too, because people they're sensing they're not getting the whole truth and nothing but the truth. They're not getting it.

So my agency, BillOReilly.com, the No Spin News, we do provide that. And you know, when somebody attacks me or whatever, I just slay them with the facts, Jason. I've always done it. I always will do it. I just hit them boom, boom, boom, boom. And they're staggering.
All right. And because of that, these independent news agencies are growing exponentially. And I think that's a positive for the country.
Listen, I don't tell me what you really believe. I don't have an agenda with this question, but I'm someone that thinks there's a one guy out there that's a huge exception.
I love what Tucker Carlson's doing. I believe that he does have a sense of news judgment. He does have a commitment to truth wherever it leads. I don't think he's perfect.

But somehow I think they stumbled into a worthy replacement for you in the O'Reilly factor. And again, you don't have to agree or I'm not looking for a specific answer, but I want your take on Tucker Carlson.
I think he's the most important voice out there on cable news at this point.
Well, he's certainly a skilled communicator and he's doing very well gathering an audience.
But it's not news, reportage. He's coming at it from a worldview.
And the worldview is held by millions of Americans who want to watch what he says because just like you, Jason, he is fearless.
So he'll say things that no one else will say. And when you get into that position, you're going to attract an audience.
So my analysis of him, he's very effective at what he does. It's totally different than what I did. He is successful in doing what he does. I don't think it hurts the country.
And it's entertaining. He knows how to do this kind of thing. But you'll remember back when I was on, I always brought in or tried to get the smartest person who disagreed with me.
Right?
John Stewart.
I told my step. Get me the best of the best and go up against me in a debate.
That's not what happens anymore. It's kind of an echo chamber in all the shows.
And to me, I would rather see a really spirited debate with two intelligent people than just my opinion reinforced over and over again.
I'm going to back you up on that to say that there was a time when Jimmy, when me and Bill didn't always get along.
But Bill always wanted me on his show. And had me on his show for you.
It's not that we disagreed on everything because a lot of times he brought me on on things that he agreed with me.
But when we did disagree, he still wanted me to come on his show.
And so I respect that.
I think that we're in a different era though now where the left is afraid to engage with people they disagree with.
And I think it's much harder. Bill, I've read and I want to ask you this.
You're planning to do a speaking tour with former President Trump?
Yes, one of the things about the Trump era, the four years that he was in the Oval Office was we didn't get, as you pointed out earlier in the program, honest reporting.
So people don't know what Trump did or did not do and why.
They don't know. They don't know how the vaccine got up and running so quickly.
They don't know what the deal he made with the Taliban actually was.
They don't know how the border, how those massive caravans stopped.
They don't know any of that.
So I put together four shows with the former President in December.
The first one is Lauderdale, December 11th, Orlando December 12th, Houston, the next Saturday, and Dallas the next Sunday.
And it's all history.
No relittigating the election, no campaigning, me and Donald Trump, mono, mono history.
Now, if you doubt my veracity or my ability, just Google a Riley Trump interviews from the Presidential campaign.
And far and away, they were the best ever done with the man.
He will tell you that. And there were no cupcake interviews, Jason.
So this history tour is going to make history because of people who come to it.
And I will have all a video and I'll use selected parts of it on the nose.
It's on bill O'Reilly dot com.
They will learn a lot about what happened because they don't know now.
Bill will end on this note sticking with President Trump, former President Trump.
Do you think in 2024, Donald Trump would be the best Republican candidate for President?
